body.p: Which distribution is a plausible representation of the sampling distribution for random samples of 30 students?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The mean of the sampling distribution should be p = 0.62. The mean of this distribution is 0.50.

Correct. The mean of the sampling distribution should be p = 0.62 with standard deviation sqrt( p(1 - p) / n ) = sqrt( 0.62(1 - 0.62 ) / 30) = 0.09. Typical values should fall within one standard deviation of the mean, from about 0.53 to 0.71. This distribution fits this description, as shown in the graph.

Incorrect. The mean of the sampling distribution should be p = 0.62 with a standard deviation of sqrt( p(1 - p) / n ) = sqrt( 0.62(1 - 0.62) / 30 ) ≅ 0.09. Graph C has a mean of approximately 0.62, but the standard deviation looks larger than 0.09. To see this, mark 1 standard deviation on either side of the mean. The Standard Deviation Rule tells us that 68% of the sample proportions will fall within this range. It looks like less than half of the values fall between 0.53 and 0.71 in Graph C.

The Standard Deviation Rule tells us that 68% of the sample proportions will fall within this range. It looks like most of the values fall between 0.53 and 0.71 in Graph D.

part.hint: The distribution of sample proportions has a mean of p and a standard deviation of sqrt( p(1 - p) / n) .
p is the population proportion. In this scenario, p is the proportion of graduates from public universities who have student loans. n is the sample size.

Plug in p = 0.62 and n = 30. Look for a graph with a mean of approximately 0.62 and standard deviation of approximately 0.09. We know from the Standard Deviation Rule that roughly 68% of the sample proportions will fall within 1 standard deviation of the mean.
